title: Dual-MCU Development Boards
description: A set of dual-MCU boards, named the EDGE-A and EDGE-B using UART communication between an ESP32-S3 chip and a RP2354B / Kendryte K210 depending on the model. These boards have integrated sensor arrays containing IMUs, Microphones, ToF and dual inbuilt DC motor controllers. These systems saw significant gains when compared to single-MCU microcontrollers. The research paper can be found here. This project will is sponsored by Sipeed and EasyEDA, and will be participating in Buckeye Science & Engineering Fair 2026 and Regeneron Science Talent Search 2025.

title: IoT Weatherstation Board
description: A comprehensive environmental monitoring system designed for autonomous outdoor deployment. This weather station combines meteorological sensors, air quality monitoring, and power management into a single robust PCB design.

title: Compact ESP32 Development Board
description: Part of the same series as the EDGE-A/B, the CORE is an ultra-compact ESP32-S3 development board designed to be approximately the size of a penny while maintaining full functionality. This miniaturized board demonstrates advanced PCB design principles, component selection optimization, and space-efficient layout techniques. The project showcases expertise in high-density circuit design, signal integrity monitoring, and manufacturing constraints for small-form-factor electronics. Features include all essential GPIO breakouts, an integrated IMU, USB-C programming interface, and integrated antenna design within the compact footprint. This board has been used in a small, centimeter accurate room-scale tracking system, in addition to asynchronous environment tracking sensor, spread out over my school's campus.

title: NODE-C1: Kendryte K210 AI Module
description: A compute expansion module for the EDGE and CORE modules, built around the Kendryte K210 (MAIX M1) AI chip. Designed for embedded machine learning and computer vision applications, the module provides independent compute power alongside an ESP32-S3 host. Featuring dual-core RISC-V processors, hardware-accelerated neural network inference, this module enables real-time object detection and classification in edge devices. It communicates with the main system via UART and can be programmed through its dedicated USB-C port.

title: NODE-N1: LoRa Networking Module
description: A communication expansion module for the EDGE and CORE modules, using the SX1276 LoRa transceiver for long-range, low-power wireless networking. This module is designed for IoT telemetry, environmental monitoring, and distributed robotics applications. It enables secure peer-to-peer or gateway-based networking with configurable bandwidth and spreading factors, communicating with the board via SPI. Optimized for integration with ESP32-based systems, this module supports kilometer-scale data transmission while maintaining ultra-low power draw.

title: NODE-M1: Motor Control Module
description: A compact motor control module for the EDGE and CORE modules, using the DRV8833PW dual H-Bridge motor driver IC. Configured to control a single DC motor with three input signals (SLEEP, AIN1, AIN2), this module provides reliable low-voltage motor control for robotics and embedded systems. Designed for integration with higher-level compute modules, NODE-M1 enables precise PWM-based motor actuation through simple I/O communication.

title: Differential Swerve Drive Module
description: A robotics project using CAD design, 3D printing and CNC machining to create a fully functional differential swerve drive module from scratch, as well as Java programming to implement autonomous navigation with the system, using real time rotary and motor encoder feedback. Calculus-based kinematics and physics principles were applied to optimize movement and turning.

title: Rocket Stabilization System
description: A custom flight control system for model rockets, using a GY-521 IMU in addition to other sensors to maintain stability in flight. Consisted of a custom SAMD21 control board, sensor array and TVC gimbal. Built with principles from OSU Physics and Engineering courses. This project won a Grand Award and Air Force Engineering Innovation award at Buckeye Science & Engineering Fair 2025 as well qualifying for Regeneron International Science & Engineering Fair 2025.
